TASK.md

L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: tumor-vaccine-ici
L4: Task title: mRNA tumor sensitization for checkpoint blockade
L5: Reference paper: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L6: Reference URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/study_overview.json` (schema: `schemas/study_overview.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/quantitative_findings.json` (schema: `schemas/quantitative_findings.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/claim_audit.json` (schema: `schemas/claim_audit.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/public_summary.json` (schema: `schemas/public_summary.schema.json`)
L20: 
L21: ## Constraints
L22: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L23: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L24: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L25: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L26: - Use relative paths only.
L27: - Never use absolute paths.
L28: - Never use `..` in paths.
L29: - Write valid JSON only.
L30: 
L31: ## Completion
L32: Respond with a checklist of written output files.
L33: After the checklist, stop. Do not call more tools.

claim_audit.schema.json
public_summary.schema.json
quantitative_findings.schema.json
study_overview.schema.json

L1: # Structured Paper Report: Tumor Sensitization by mRNA Vaccination
L2: 
L3: ## Citation
L4: - Title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L5: - Journal: Nature
L6: - Year: 2025
L7: - DOI: 10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8
L8: - Source URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L9: 
L10: ## One-Paragraph Context
L11: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) can produce durable responses in some cancers, but many tumors remain non-responsive due to weak antigen presentation or poor immune priming. The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
L12: 
L13: ## Study Design Snapshot
L14: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
L15: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
L16: - Mechanistic probes: immunopeptidomics, transcriptomics, and perturbation controls (including IFNAR1 blockade and non-mRNA particle controls).
L17: 
L18: ## Cohorts and Scenarios
L19: 1. Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy): 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments.
L20: 2. Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle): 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls.
L21: 3. Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.
L22: 4. Human vaccinated subgroup: 43 patients.
L23: 5. Human unvaccinated subgroup: 87 patients.
L24: 
L25: ## Quantitative Findings
L26: | Metric | Vaccine/Combination Arm | Comparator | Interpretation |
L27: |---|---:|---:|---|
L28: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
L29: | Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
L30: | Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
L31: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
L32: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
L33: | Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
L34: 
L35: ## Controls and Null/Conditional Results
L36: - Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
L37: - ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
L38: - Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
L39: - Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
L40: 
L41: ## Mechanistic Chain Proposed by Authors
L42: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
L43: 2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
L44: 3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
L45: 4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
L46: 5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
L47: 
L48: ## Caveats and Threats to Validity
L49: - The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
L50: - Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
L51: - Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
L52: - Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
L53: - Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
L54: 
L55: ## Practical Takeaway
L56: The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.
Successfully wrote file: output/study_overview.json
Successfully wrote file: output/quantitative_findings.json
Successfully wrote file: output/claim_audit.json

L1: {
L2:   "paper": {
L3:     "title": "SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade",
L4:     "doi": "10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8",
L5:     "publication_year": 2025,
L6:     "domain": "oncology-immunology",
L7:     "study_type": "preclinical+retrospective"
L8:   },
L9:   "core_question": "Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination increase tumor sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade, and are the findings consistent in both murine models and retrospective human ICI-treated patients?",
L10:   "datasets_or_cohorts": [
L11:     {
L12:       "id": "mouse-efficacy-cohort",
L13:       "label": "Mouse efficacy cohort",
L14:       "sample_size_or_observations": "78 mice (pooled across repeat experiments)",
L15:       "description": "Murine efficacy studies testing intratumoral mRNA vaccination combined with anti-PD-L1 in multiple tumor models."
L16:     },
L17:     {
L18:       "id": "mouse-control-cohort",
L19:       "label": "Mouse control cohort",
L20:       "sample_size_or_observations": "84 mice (pooled across matched controls)",
L21:       "description": "Matched murine controls receiving vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle treatment for comparison against sensitization outcomes."
L22:     },
L23:     {
L24:       "id": "human-retrospective-cohort",
L25:       "label": "Human retrospective cohort",
L26:       "sample_size_or_observations": "130 metastatic patients",
L27:       "description": "Metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors, analyzed retrospectively by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status."
L28:     },
L29:     {
L30:       "id": "human-vaccinated-subgroup",
L31:       "label": "Human vaccinated subgroup",
L32:       "sample_size_or_observations": "43 patients",
L33:       "description": "Subset of the retrospective cohort previously vaccinated with a SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine before/around ICI treatment."
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "id": "human-unvaccinated-subgroup",
L37:       "label": "Human unvaccinated subgroup",
L38:       "sample_size_or_observations": "87 patients",
L39:       "description": "Comparison group of metastatic patients without documented SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for survival and clinical outcome contrasts."
L40:     }
L41:   ],
L42:   "major_limitations": [
L43:     "The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely. ",
L44:     "Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients. ",
L45:     "Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation. ",
L46:     "Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors. ",
L47:     "Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all settings. "
L48:   ]
L49: }

L2:   "headline": "Tumor-targeted mRNA vaccines may prime cancers for stronger anti-PD-L1 responses",
L3:   "plain_language_summary": "Researchers tested whether giving an mRNA vaccine directly inside a tumor can make that tumor more sensitive to immune checkpoint blockade. In a separate retrospective review of 130 metastatic patients on ICI treatment, vaccinated patients (43) had better survival
L4:   ",
L5:   "what_is_new": [
L6:     "The work links local mRNA vaccination in the tumor with broadening of the tumor immunopeptidome and MHC-I presented antigens, which can improve immune recognition of the tumor. ",
L7:     "It combines murine efficacy experiments with a real-world metastatic patient analysis to connect mechanism, preclinical response, and retrospective clinical associations. ",
L8:     "Mechanistically, the effect appears tied to type I interferon signaling, with anti-IFNAR1 blockade abolishing sensitization and non-mRNA lipid particles failing to mimic the benefit."
L9:   ],
L10:   "why_caution_is_needed": [
L11:     "The human comparison was retrospective and non-randomized, so unmeasured confounding and baseline group differences could influence survival associations. ",
L12:     "Vaccination timing relative to ICI start varied across patients, making it hard to attribute timing-specific efficacy claims to the vaccine effect alone. ",
L13:     "Tumor-type mix and prior treatment heterogeneity were present, and mouse-to-human translation is not guaranteed across all cancers and contexts. "
L14:   ],
L15:   "glossary": [
L16:     {
L17:       "term": "ICI",
L18:       "definition": "Immune checkpoint inhibitors; drugs like anti-PD-L1 that block inhibitory signals on immune cells so T-cells can attack tumors more effectively."
L19:     },
L20:     {
L21:       "term": "MHC-I",
L22:       "definition": "A surface molecule type on cells that presents protein fragments to CD8+ T-cells, helping immune cells recognize cancer cells."
L23:     },
L24:     {
L25:       "term": "Interferon signaling",
L26:       "definition": "A cell communication pathway (especially type I interferons) that increases antiviral-like immune activation and antigen presentation in tissues."
L27:     },
L28:     {
L29:       "term": "Immunopeptidome",
L30:       "definition": "The full set of peptides displayed on MHC molecules by a cell, which can be measured to estimate how visible that cell is to the immune system."
L31:     }
L32:   ],
L33:   "open_questions": [
L34:     "Do these findings hold in a prospective randomized human trial with predefined vaccination timing and standardized ICI regimens? ",
L35:     "Which specific tumor types and prior-therapy backgrounds benefit most, and which derive little or no benefit from this sensitization approach? ",
L36:     "Can biomarkers from the interferon and antigen-presentation signatures be used to select patients most likely to benefit before treatment? "
L37:   ]
L38: }

output/public_summary.json:3:  "plain_language_summary": "Researchers tested whether giving an mRNA vaccine directly inside a tumor can make that tumor more sensitive to immune checkpoint blockade. In mice, combining intratumoral mRNA vaccination with anti-PD-L1 was linked to stronger immune signatures, including broader antigen presentation, higher PD-L1 expression, and more CD8+ T-cell infiltration. In a separate retrospective review of 130 metastatic patients on ICI treatment, vaccinated patients (43) had better survival signals than unvaccinated patients (87), with a reported p-value of 0.01. The study also found that the benefit depended on type I interferon pathways and was lost when interferon signaling was blocked, and non-mRNA particle controls failed to reproduce the effect. While encouraging, the human signal is observational and not randomized, so larger prospective trials are still needed before changing clinical practice.
